I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 

1. 
to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Namangan 500-Kilovolt Power Transmission Project.1 
 
The project will erect new high-voltage transmission assets to secure the power supply 
2. 
to  Fergana  Valley  and  implement  institutional  changes  in  the  power  utility  company, 
Uzbekenergo.  The  project  will  increase  energy  security  through  the  diversification  and 
expansion of energy supply routes. It will improve power supply reliability in the country and, in 
particular,  the  Namangan,  Fergana,  and  Andijon  provinces;  reduce  transmission  losses;  and 
improve the operational efficiency of the power sector.2 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

A. 
 
3. 
The establishment of a Central Asian transmission system started during the Soviet era 
in  the  1960s.  The  transmission  lines  connecting  the  power  plants  and  substations  feeding  the 
load centers are at 500 kilovolt (kV) and 220 kV levels. The transmission system was designed 
following the technical and geographical requirements to benefit from the diversified energy and 
water resources in Central Asia. Yet, the locations of the substations and the line routing did not 
take into account the countries’ borders, as these were considered not relevant at that time. 
 
4. 
The power grid of Uzbekistan is a major component of the integrated and synchronized 
high-voltage power transmission network of the Central Asian power system. The Coordinating 
Dispatch Center in Tashkent manages network operation and planning. Trading arrangements 
between the countries are constrained by aging infrastructure, as well as varied energy sector 
development priorities of each participating country after independence. The reliable and secure 
operation of the transmission network is a prerequisite for power trade to reduce the economic 
cost of electricity for Uzbekistan and its neighbors. 
 
5. 
A  poorly  designed  transmission  grid  and  associated  capacity  constraints  became  an 
acute  problem,  particularly  for  the  most  densely  populated  region  of  Uzbekistan,  Fergana 
Valley. More than 8 million people and several large industries in the region are supplied from 
the main Uzbek grid (400 megawatts [MW]), the Kyrgyz Republic (1,300 MW), and generation in 
Fergana (100 MW). As demand increases, the underdeveloped local transmission grid impedes 
the  reliable supply  of  power  to domestic  customers.  During the  3-month  summer  period,  peak 
demand reaches  2,000 MW, creating  overload  in the  current  220 kV transmission  system  that 
leads  to  a  voltage  drop  of  185 kV.  This  results  in  a  responsive  action  by  Uzbekenergo: 
disconnecting  customers  to  reduce  the  load  by  an  average  of  150  MW.  Registered  cases  of 
voltage  drops  to  100  kV  have  resulted  in  the  disconnection  of  80%  of  customers  in  Fergana, 
followed by a cascading effect of disconnections even in Kazakhstan. Regular maintenance of 
the  grid  is  also  impossible  without  disconnection  of  a  significant  number  of  customers. 
Therefore,  additional  transmission  capacity  is  urgently  needed  to  satisfy  current  and  future 
power  demand  and  to  undertake  proper  maintenance,  which  contributes  to  high  voltage  grid 
stability in Uzbekistan and its neighbors. 
 
6. 
Facing  the  challenges  in  energy  security,  deteriorating  infrastructure,  and  unreliable 
power supply, the Government of Uzbekistan has taken various initiatives. It approved a 5-year 
rolling investment plan amounting to $5 billion to rehabilitate and upgrade energy infrastructure.

 2 

It  also  commenced  institutional  improvements  to  increase  the  transparency  and  operational 
efficiency  of  the  electricity  sector.  It  reorganized  and  reinforced  the  investment  unit  at  the 
vertically  integrated  state-owned  power  utility  company,  Uzbekenergo,  to  implement  new 
investment  projects  more  effectively.  Actions  have  been  taken  to  improve  the  financial 
performance  of  the  company.  A  loss-reduction  program  was  initiated  by  adopting  advanced 
meters  to  increase  collections  and  reduce  losses.  Cost  centers  for  generation,  transmission, 
and  distribution  have  been  split.  Each  unit  has  a  separate  accounting  department  and 
implementation  of  international  financial  reporting  standards-based  financial  statements  to 
improve  financial  management  is  ongoing.  Electricity  tariffs  have  been  gradually  increasing  to 
ensure the cost recovery level is maintained. 
 
7. 
Although a number of institutional changes have been initiated, little attention has been 
paid  to  improvements  in  the  company’s  core  operations.  There  is  substantial  room  for  cost 
savings  by  improving  the  efficiency  of  system maintenance,  planning,  and budgeting;  and  this 
could  be  achieved  using  external  expertise.  Since  the  investments  under  this  project  are 
focused  on transmission,  Uzbekenergo has  requested  assistance  for  the  reorganization of  the 
transmission  asset  management  department  to  improve  efficient  budget  provisioning  for 
maintenance  and  optimize  scheduling.  The  transmission  system  planning  department  is  also 
inadequate to meet present sector needs. Lack of modern tools and skills makes it impossible to 
plan  an  optimal  system  and,  thus,  optimize  investments.  Both  departments  need  to  be 
trained  personnel.  Further 
restructured,  and  equipped  with  modern 
institutional and operational improvements in the generation and distribution subsectors will be 
implemented under the relevant investment projects, which are in the pipeline. 
  
In  2012,  the  power  sector  regional  master  plan  was  prepared  under  Central  Asia 
8. 
Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC). 3  According  to  the  master  plan,  the  Namangan 
project  is  a  least-cost  solution  to  bring  additional  power  to  Fergana  since  the  region  does  not 
have  hydro  or  fossil  fuel  reserves  for  new  local  generation,  and  no  additional  power  import  is 
available  from  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  The  solution  is  to  bring  more  power  from  Uzbekistan’s 
central  grid  by  adding  transmission  capacity.  The  master  plan  identified  the  project  as  having 
principal importance for the reliability of the Central Asian transmission grid to support regional 
power trade. 
 
9. 
The  project  is  a  government  priority,  and  it  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) to provide financial support. The project is included in ADB’s country operations business 
plan,  2011–20134 and  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2020.5 It  will  be  the  third  project  loan 
intervention in Uzbekistan’s power sector, with focus on transmission. The first two loans were 
in the generation6 and distribution7 subsectors, and implementation is at the procurement stage. 
 
B. 
 
10. 
The impact of the project will be improved reliability of power supply in Uzbekistan. The 
outcome  of  the  project  will  be  an  expanded  and  modernized  high  voltage  transmission  grid 
providing adequate and reliable power supply to Fergana Valley.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

Economic and Financial 

A. 
 
20. 
ADB conducted technical due diligence on the investment proposal and is satisfied with 
the quality  of the  cost  estimates,  operating  cost structures,  appropriateness of the technology, 
and the execution plan. The readiness level is high and the technical solutions are assessed to 
be more cost-effective than the alternatives. Uzbekenergo’s operation and maintenance staff is 
familiar  with  the  proposed  design  concepts.  The  technical  proposals  do  not  represent  a  shift 
from existing practices. Uzbekenergo has sufficient technical capacity and experienced staff to 
undertake construction of this project.11 
 
21. 
Transmission  system  planning  and  transmission  asset  management  systems  are  a 
standard  power  utility  practice  based  on  proven technology  and considered  appropriate  in  this 
case. These systems are a technological step change for the company. This will require training 
to be included in the terms of reference for consultants and contractors. This is routine practice 
for a utility when first implementing similar systems. Investment sites were visited by consultants 
and  ADB  staff.  The  contracts  will  include  sufficient  spare  parts  and  quality  and  performance 
guarantees. 
 
B. 
 
22. 
The economic viability is assessed for the overall project based on expected streams of 
benefits  and  costs  resulting  from  the  construction,  installation,  and  operations  of  the  project 
components  over  their  economic  lives.  The  project  is  economically  viable,  as  the  economic 
internal  rate  of  return  in  the  base  case  of  23.1%  exceeds  the  economic  opportunity  cost  of 
capital,  assumed  at  12.0%.  The  sensitivity  analysis  shows  that  the  economic  internal  rate  of 
return remains viable even in the case of increased capital expenditure and reduced benefits. 
 
23. 
The financial internal rate of return of the project is 4.8%, which compares favorably with 
the estimated weighted average cost of capital of 0.8%, indicating expected financial viability for 
the  project.  Financial  viability  was  gauged  by  comparing  the  costs  and  benefits  in  with-  and 
without-project investment scenarios. Quantified benefits include enhanced reliability, increased 
consumption, and avoided system losses. The sensitivity analysis shows that project viability is 
robust  to  capital  and  operational  expenditure  increases,  as  well  as  reductions  of  the  revenue 
stream earned by Uzbekenergo.

debt and Uzbekenergo’s internal sources, can be implemented without putting undue stress on

the cost of services and inflation. Since 2004, the nominal tariff for electricity has increased at a 
rate higher than 15% per year, or almost five times, from SUM20 per kilowatt-hour to SUM97.5 
per  kilowatt-hour.  Continued  tariff  increases  above  the  inflation  rate  remain  important  for  the 
power utility to achieve a sustainable financial performance without subsidy. The government is 
committed to maintaining cost of service tariffs for electricity. 
 
C. 
 
The  government  has  undertaken  a  series  of  measures  to  strengthen  its  national 
26. 
governance, including (i) legal reforms to improve the judiciary and courts; (ii) reforms to public 
sector management, especially public financial management and tax reforms; (iii) measures to 
make  the  private  sector more  competitive;  and  (iv)  more  transparent  procurement  procedures. 
Progress has been made in public financial management, including the adoption of the Budget 
System  Law  and  Treasury  Law  approved  in  2007  and  the  public  expenditure  reform  process 
covering 2007–2018. Uzbekistan acceded to the United Nations Convention against Corruption 
in July 2008.

financial and accounting policy that adopts accrual accounting, double-entry bookkeeping, and 
other  generally  accepted  accounting  principles  and  conventions  in  compliance  with  national 
standards. Capacity development under the ongoing Talimarjan Power Project is strengthening

D. 
 
30. 
The project will increase access to a more reliable form of electricity for people living in 
Fergana  Valley.  The  region  will  become  a  better  place  that  provides  more  labor-based  wage 
employment  opportunities,  as  industry  will  have  the  necessary  inducement  to  relocate  to  the 
Fergana.  This  will  prevent  the  need  for  labor  to  move  elsewhere  to  Commonwealth  of 
Independent  States  countries,  especially  the  Russian Federation,  in search of non-agriculture-
based  wage  labor  employment  opportunities.  Andijon,  with  9%  of  Uzbekistan’s  population, 
currently  produces  21.5%  of  Uzbekistan’s  non-agriculture-based  outputs,  but  Fergana  and 
Namangan are less industrialized and more rural. This has an obvious beneficial social impact 
on such households because many adult income-earners, especially males, are not required to 
be absent from households for an extended period of time. Such households are able to retain 
or  enhance  their  social  capital  in  ways  not  formerly  possible  where  adult  household  members 
are typically absent because of lack of local employment opportunities. 
 
E. 
 

Safeguards  

1. 

Environmental Assessment 

 
31. 
Environmental  categorization  of  the  project  is  B  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009). An initial environmental examination (IEE) was prepared, and potential 
affected  people  were  consulted.  Uzbekenergo  cleared  the  IEE  report  and  it  was  disclosed  via 
ADB’s  website  on  1  August  2012.  The  transmission  lines  run  through  areas  with  low 
environmental sensitivities. No significant or irreversible impacts are expected with the operation 
of  the  new  lines.  There  will  be  some  temporary  impacts  during  the  construction  phase,  but 
mitigation measures have been developed. The environmental management plan has also been 
prepared  as  part  of  the  IEE  to  ensure  that  adequate  resources  are  allocated  to  handle  the 
impact. Mitigation measures could be included as part of the construction costs. Implementation 
of the environmental management plan will be recorded and reported through a project quarterly 
report,  and  a  stand-alone  environmental  monitoring  report  will  be  submitted  annually  to  ADB. 
PMU  staff  has  been  involved  in  similar  projects  financed  by  other  multilateral  financial 
institutions  and  they  have  sufficient  capacity  to  manage  the  environmental  safeguards. 
Environmental  specialists  of  the  implementation  consultants  will  provide  additional  support  to 
the PMU. 
 
 
 
32. 
The  project  is  categorized  C  for  indigenous  peoples  safeguard.  The  field  social  survey 
found no ethnic minority, as described in ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 2009, involved or 
affected by the project. The project is category B for involuntary resettlement safeguard. A land 
acquisition  and  resettlement  plan  (LARP)  for  the  transmission  lines  has  been  prepared  based 
on  the  preliminary  design  of  the  project,  in  close  consultation  with  affected  households.  A 
detailed socioeconomic survey was carried out. Uzbekenergo submitted the LARP to ADB and it 
was  disclosed  via  ADB’s  website  on  1  August  2012.  Uzbekenergo  will  update  the  LARP  after 
finalizing the detailed design and submit it to ADB for approval. 
 

Social Assessment

 The  project  will  permanently  acquire  21.9  hectares  (ha), 12  of  which  11.7  ha  is 
33. 
government  unallocated  land.  About  346.2  ha  will  be  temporarily  acquired  for  use  during  the 
construction  period,  of  which  212.8  ha  is  government  unallocated  land.  Affected  households 
total 145, with 1,003 affected people. Seventeen affected households or 109 affected people will 
lose  shelter  and  be  relocated  as  much  as  possible  in  the  immediate  vicinity  of  their  original 
homes.  Almost  all  affected  households  will  be  affected  by  two  impacts—land  and  crops;  only 
one affected household will lose almost 10% of its productive land. The total compensation for 
land acquisition, temporary and permanent, will be about $2 million.  
 
34.  Monitoring the implementation of LARP will be done on a quarterly basis and the report 
will be submitted to ADB. The report will include the number of affected households who were 
paid  compensation,  monetary  value  of  paid  compensation,  and  location  where  compensation 
has been completely executed and demolition of structures, if any. The report on completion of 
LARP  implementation,  especially  on  payment  of  compensation,  should  be  submitted  to  ADB 
prior to commencement of any field works for the transmission line.
